_exec_summary.SummaryText:
LA 0002452035
Promix Fractionator Facility
Operated by Enterprise Products Operating L.P.
Promix Fractionation Facility
6225 Hwy 996
Belle Rose, Louisiana 70341

EPA Facility Identifier:  1000 0009 1296            


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP)

The Promix Facility is committed to being associated with exceptional safety and environmental performance as measured by our employees, customers, and the public.  Our management philosophy goals are achieved by the personal commitments of our employees and contractors, and by open communication with our employees, customers, and neighbors.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs we have at our facilities are part of the high standards we strive for.  Our high standards are achieved by operating in compliance with all required environmental permits and regulations, by operating and maintaining our assets in such a manner that any unpermitted release will be unintentional and acknowledged as unacceptable by remedying any shortcomings found during regular audits of our facilities, and by reporting promptly to regulators any shortcomings found during the course of our audits as required by law.

The Promix Fractionator is owned by K/D/S Promix, LLC.  Enterprise Products Operating L.P. (Enterprise) became the operator of the plant.

At the facility, the plant receives natural gas liquids (NGL) as feedstock from natural gas processing facilities.  The incoming plant feed is fed directly into the plant by pipeline with any excess feed being diverted by pipeline to the underground storage caverns located nearby.  When the quantity of feed supply from the process gas plants is insufficient, supplemental feedstock from the underground storage caverns are returned back to the plant feed system (by pipeline) as feedstock.  This feedstock is treated (for removal of CO2) prior to entering the fractionation process.  This is accomplished by an Amine system, which uses a Diethanolamaine and Methyldie

thanolamine mixture to remove the CO2.  

The facility has a capability to fractionate the feedstock into six product streams:

    Purity Ethane
Ethane/Propane (E-P) Mix
    Propane
    Iso-Butane
    Normal Butane
    Natural Gasoline

These product streams are further purified to remove contaminants such as water and mercaptans.  The purity products are stored either in tanks or underground storage caverns (by pipeline).  These products are distributed to various customers via pipeline, barge or transport trucks.  Chlorine is the only regulated toxic substance on site.  The previously listed chemicals are flammable substances regulated under the RMP.  The facility is classified as a Program Level 3 under the regulation.  The purpose of the RMP is to provide information about our operations, our programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, our emergency response plans in case of an accidental release, our five-year accident history and our planned changes to improve safety at the facility.

WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO

We have analyzed and performed the simulated "Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenarios" for both the toxic substance and the flammable substances.  Details of these models are within the reporting of the RMP that is being filed with the EPA.  All distant calculations were based on the EPA's RMP*Comp (Version 1.7) and the EPA OCA methods, which are known to over predict the impact potential release from such scenarios.  Although we have numerous controls to prevent such releases and manage their consequences, no credit for any control or mitigation measures were taken into account when evaluating the alternative release scenarios.

We have discussed these potential releases with our employees and with local emergency response officials in the Assumption Parish, thereby further reducing the possibility of any impact on the public.

PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Promix Fractionator has been operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administrat

ion (OSHA) Process Safety Management Program since 1992.  Our ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of our process, detailed training of our employees, and constant emphasis on safety have helped us avoid any serious accidents over the last five years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the additional prevention features implemented at this facility include:

* Hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the process area, which will sound an alarm in the control room upon detection of elevated hydrocarbon concentrations.
* Chlorine gas detectors around the process area.
* Fire Water system consisting of fire extinguishers, fire monitors and firewater deluge system for fire fighting purposes.
* Emergency Shutdown (ESD) systems have been installed and recently upgraded for the entire plant.  ESD pull switches are located at various locations within the facility in order to safely shutdown the facility during an actual emergency.  An electrical ESD has been added which shuts off the entire electrical supply to the facility.  
* Burner management system has been installed in order to provide a safe air purge of furnaces during emergency shutdown of the heaters.
* Continuous pilots on the flare in order to ensure uninterrupted combustion of vented hydrocarbon gases
* Truck drivers entering the facility to load/unload are required to chock wheels and to attach grounding cables prior to loading/unloading.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, pro-active approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management Systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
*

Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As part of our prevention efforts, we have a multitude of programs in which our employees participate.  We have a training program in which the Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the plant, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  We train, use and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, which include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

We have an on-going Mechanical Integrity and Inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies in the process equipment prior to any incident.

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is observed, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

Records are maintained for all significant accidental releases of hazardous chemicals that occur at the facility.  For each of these incidents (as defined by OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard), formal incident investigations are conducted to identify and correct the root causes of the events.  There have been no RMP-defined accidental releases of hazardous material from the Promix Facility within the last five years. 

These safe guards as well as the vigilance of our trained employees have helped us operate safely at this facility since 1996.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No incident resulting in onsite or offsite impacts from a release of an RMP substance has occurred at the Promix Facility within the last five years.  Although we take pride in that record, we also place daily emphasis on our prevention and safety programs to ensure this record continues.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolida

tes all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Enterprise continues to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Promix Fractionator Facility with the Assumption Parish Volunteer Fire Department and the Assumption Parish Sheriff's Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Paincourtville Volunteer Fire Department, the Assumption Parish Office of Emergency Preparedness, Acadian Ambulance Service and the Lady of the Lake Hospital.  The Promix Fractionator Facility Manager is responsible for coordinating all emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials along with evacuation procedures, regular scheduled drills and training of the program to all employees.  Our Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which Enterprise will strive to improve the level of safety at the Promix Facility.  Some of the key components of the prevention program are as follows:

* The Enterprise Management of Change program ensures that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to the process chemicals, technology, equipment and/or procedures are considered with each and every change.
* The Process Hazard Analysis provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards.
* The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases.  Thereby serving as an integral part of our safety progr

am.
* Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we will maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
* An ongoing dialogue with the Assumption Parish Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergency as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.  In this way, we shall bolster our strong commitment to the safety of all employees and the community.
* Enterprise personnel are continuously reviewing and improving our PSM systems, especially in the areas of operating procedures and training programs.
* The PSM system is constantly being subjected to critical reviews with an objective of improving the programs.
* The written PSM management system is presently undergoing a comprehensive, thorough review, with specific emphasis being placed on the written mechanical integrity program.
* The Emergency Preparedness Plan is scheduled to be reviewed and updated in the spring of next year.
* The Safety Procedures and Policies Manual was reviewed and updated in February of 2003

We encourage all interested citizens or community organizations to contact the Assumption Parish Emergency Management Director for the latest information on emergency response for the Parish on an ongoing basis.
